description:
Mythimna ferrago, commonly known as the Tawny Marbled Minor, is a species of moth belonging to the family Noctuidae. This species is native to Europe, where it can be found in various habitats, including grasslands, meadows, and forests.

The Tawny Marbled Minor has a wingspan of approximately 30-35 millimeters. Its forewings are typically light brown to reddish-brown in color, with darker mottled patterns that give the moth a marbled appearance. The hindwings are greyish-white, often with a darker margin.

The larvae, or caterpillars, of Mythimna ferrago feed on a variety of grasses and other low-growing plants. They are typically green or brown in color, with a distinct pattern of longitudinal stripes along their bodies.

The Tawny Marbled Minor is known to have a single generation per year, with adults emerging during the summer months. They are primarily nocturnal, attracted to artificial light sources, and can be observed resting on vegetation during the day.

This species is considered a common and widespread moth within its natural range, and it plays a role in the local ecosystem as a consumer of grasses and other plant matter.
